JavaScriptâ„¢? Weekly

'Oracle, Itâ€™s Time to Free JavaScript.' â€” Itâ€™s long been a bone of contention that Oracle owns the trademark for â€˜JavaScriptâ€™ (we put out a call two years ago) but this marks the first serious effort to try and change that, including petitioning the USPTO, if necessary. You can support the effort by signing this open letter, joining a vast array of JavaScriptÂ luminaries.

The JavaScript Community

Now You Can Compile and Run C in JavaScript â€” Well, if youâ€™re using Bun, at least. Bun v1.1.28 lands experimental support for compiling and native C code and then running its functions fromÂ JavaScript. It's easier than itÂ sounds..

Jarred Sumner (Bun)

ğŸ˜… Bun's creator said this is "an unplanned feature I worked on mostly a month ago on a Saturday for fun" â€“ that's our kindaÂ fun!

âœ‚ï¸ Cut Your QA Cycles Down from Hours to Minutes with QA Wolf â€” If slow QA processes bottleneck your software engineering team and youâ€™re releasing slower because of it, you must check out QA Wolf. QA Wolf gets engineering teams to 80% automated end-to-end test coverage and helps them ship 2x faster by reducing QA cycles from hours to minutes. LearnÂ more.

QA Wolf sponsor

ts-blank-space: Fast Type-Stripping TypeScript to JS Compiler â€” Itâ€™s job is simple: be the fastest TS to JS compiler written in JS (itâ€™s 5.6x faster than tsc.) Types are simply replaced with whitespace preserving the coordinates of the JS code which eliminates the need for sourcemapsÂ entirely.

Ashley Claymore / Bloomberg

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ† Developer analyst firm RedMonk has put out a Q3 2024 ranking of programming languages with JavaScript happily in firstÂ place.

  • ğŸ“º Honeypot has released a nine minute documentary where Ryan Dahl (the original creator of Node.js) and Bert Belder â–¶ï¸ tell the story of how Deno began.

  • Talking of Deno, Deno 2.0 is expected to be released tomorrow.

  • ğŸ§­ Alongside new releases of macOS, iOS, and iPadOS, Safari 18 has been released. Alongside numerous Web API enhancements, its JS regex support has been enhanced when it comes toÂ Unicode.

  • ğŸ”¥ David Bushell tried JSR â€“ he didn't like it.

RELEASES:

  • Fastify v5 â€“ Fastify is a popular, perf-focused web framework for Node.js, inspired by Express (which recently reached v5.0 too!)

  • Astro 5 Beta â€“ Astro helps keep the run of v5.0 releases going..

  • Node.js v22.9 (Current) â€“ Adds a util.getCallSite function to obtain the stacktrace of the current execution. V8's Maglev JIT is also disabled for reliability reasons due to outstanding issues inÂ V8.

  • Hono 4.6 â€“ The nifty 'any runtime' webapp framework gains context storageÂ middleware.

ViteConf is October 3rd! â€” StackBlitz is r(ai)sing the bar in the ViteConf '24 keynote. You wonâ€™t want to miss itÂ ğŸ‘€.

StackBlitz sponsor

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Mathematical Symbols and JavaScript Equivalents â€” Weâ€™re not just talking the obvious like + and - but things like â¿âˆš, Î£, Î , âˆƒ, and setÂ notation.

Joshua Nussbaum

A React 19 Cheat Sheet â€” From Kent C Dodds, of Epic React fame, comes this part cheat sheet, part succinct reminder of some of the new things you can do in ReactÂ 19, along with (very) brief codeÂ examples.

Kent C. Dodds

[Workshop] Fix Your Front-End 101: JavaScript Edition â€” Learn practical tips to debug JavaScript end to end. Join our JavaScript team live on SeptÂ 24.

Sentry sponsor

From Parcel to Vite: A Short Story of a 100K LOC Migration â€” â€œWeâ€™ve migrated our frontend projects from Parcel to Vite, and the process wasâ€¦ smooth.â€

Gao / Logto

How to Create a Chrome Extension with React, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS and Vite â€” Covers everything you need to know right through to publishing in the Chrome WebÂ Store.

Lokman Musliu

ğŸ“º Building a React-Powered TODO App in 9 Steps â€“ A 54 second video showing off the key stages, all without any libraries exceptÂ React. Danny Thompson

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

date-fns v4.0 Released with First-Class Time Zones Support â€” date-fns is a hugely popular and comprehensive suite of 200+ functions for working with dates in JavaScript, and now thereâ€™s first-class time zone supportÂ too.

Sasha Koss

ts-remove-unused: Remove Unused Code from TypeScript Projects â€” A tool that can auto-fix unused exports (removing export from the declaration or the whole declaration based on its usage) and delete modules that have no referenced exports. Knip is another mature tool in this space, though focused more on detecting the things you canÂ remove.

LINE

Amplify the Benefits of JWTs and Session Tokens â€” Learn how leveraging the benefits of both session token authentication and JWTs results in the best of bothÂ approaches.

Clerk sponsor

Next.js SaaS Starter: A Next.js Template for SaaS Webapps â€” A starter template for building a SaaS-style webapp using Next.js with authentication, Stripe integration, and a dashboard for users. It uses Postgres and Drizzle for the database and UI elements based on shadcn/ui andÂ Tailwind.

Lee Robinson (Vercel)

nano-spawn: Tiny Execa-Inspired Process Execution for Node.js â€” If youâ€™re familiar with Sindreâ€™s Execa for running commands from a Node app in a reliable manner, nano-spawn offers its core functionality in a smaller package.

Sindre Sorhus and ehmicky

DECK.GL: GPU-Powered Large-Scale Data Visualization Framework â€” Well suited to geospatial data visualization use cases that go beyond typical 2D views. There are plenty of examples to show it off. Can be used through both vanilla JS and ReactÂ interfaces.

OpenJS Foundation

Vue-Multiselect 3.1: A Complete 'Selecting Solution' for Vue.js â€” Thereâ€™s a lot on offer here, complete with SSR support, Vuex support, strong test coverage, and with noÂ dependencies.

Damian Dulisz et al.

Chokidar 4.0: Efficient Cross-Platform File Watching Node.js Library â€” Wraps around fs.watch / fs.watchFile and normalizes the events received, applies best practices, and presents an API that works the same acrossÂ platforms.

Paul Miller

#â€‹703 â€” September 5, 2024

JavaScript Weekly

An SSR Performance Showdown â€” Fastifyâ€™s Matteo Collina set out to find the current state of server-side rendering performance across todayâ€™s most popular libraries. The first attempt faced negative feedback due to implementation issues, but the showdown has been improved andÂ re-run.

Matteo Collina

#â€‹706 â€” September 26, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Deno 2.0 Release Candidate â€” Deno started life as a manifestation of ideas that Nodeâ€™s original creator, Ryan Dahl, had after his experiences with Node. Deno 2 is the next step: how the Deno team thinks Deno should ultimately be. Many changes await: window is gone and Nodeâ€™s process appears, dependency management has been improved, numerous APIs have gone stable (e.g. WebGPU), and both Node.js API and CommonJS support have continued toÂ improve.

Bartek IwaÅ„czuk and Andy Jiang

Don't Sleep on AbortController â€” AbortController is a broadly available mechanism for, originally, aborting Web requests on demand, but you can use it for a lot more than that (or â€˜anything!â€™, as ArtemÂ explains).

Artem Zakharchenko

Learn to Build Feature-Rich, Native Mobile Apps Using React Native and Expo â€” Join Kadi Kraman for a video course designed to hone your React skills. Whether a beginner, or looking to further refine your skill set, you'll learn to create practical iOS and Android apps, covering components, styling, UX, linting, async storage, animation, and muchÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

How Josh W. Comeau Rebuilt His Blog, App Router Style â€” Weâ€™re huge fans of Joshâ€™s blog and heâ€™s just rebuilt it entirely using Next.js, MDX, Sandpack, and an array of other technologies. Here, he goes into great depth about what's involved. A good look behind the scenes of a modern React-drivenÂ project.

Josh W Comeau

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º NodeConf EU is back. It takes place in Ireland this November 3-6.

  • ğŸŸ¨ It also appears JSConf is coming back under the care of the OpenJSÂ Foundation.

  • ğŸ“Š Minification Benchmarks is a frequently updated set of benchmarks for a suite of popular JavaScriptÂ minifiers.

  • ğŸ•¹ï¸ The most recent JS13kGames gamedev contest just ended. If you want to play the entries (or do some judging yourself) they're all here. I particularly liked The Way of the Dodo andÂ Deep13.

RELEASES:

  • Bun v1.1.29 â€“ Its C compilation feature gets N-API support, but is otherwise largely a bugfixÂ release.

  • Storybook 8.3 â€“ A popular frontend component workshop is now using Vitest to rapidly speed up its component testingÂ features.

  • Strapi 5 â€“ Popular open source headlessÂ CMS.

  • Solid 1.9 â€“ Declarative and performant reactivity for buildingÂ UIs.

  • PostgreSQL 17 â€“ The popular database isn't a JavaScript project, but a lot of you will be usingÂ it. Psst! We have a Postgres newsletterÂ too!

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

A Guide to Destructuring in JavaScript â€” The destructuring assignment syntax appeared in ES6 almost ten years ago and has become a central part of modern JavaScript development. This is a good primer/reminder of theÂ potential.

Mat Marquis

The Nine Node Pillars: Principles for Doing Node Right â€” A group of prolific and productive Node.js contributors have put together a checklist to identify gaps in your current Node development practices, particularly when building large-scaleÂ apps.

Snell, Venditto, Dawson, Collina, et al.

A Complete Guide to Session Management in Next.js â€” Learn how integrating session management into your app provides robust security and enhances userÂ experience.

Clerk sponsor

What Are Durable Functions? A Visual JavaScript Primer â€” This is rather dependent on what Inngest, a durable function service, offers, but is a good primer to the general idea which may well suit your useÂ cases.

Lydia Hallie (Inngest)

What's New in Express.js 5.0 â€” Express.js 5.0 landed recently with rather brief release notes, so here's a deeper look at what it has to offer. The updates are largely incremental, but set the stage for Expressâ€™sÂ future.

Trevor I. Lasn

Angular Routing Essentials: Everything in One Post â€” A bold claim, but it does a pretty goodÂ job.

Oleksandr Kocherhin

Using Reddit's JSON API from a JavaScript App â€” How to pull data from Redditâ€™s API and display it in a simple web application built withÂ Parcel.

Muhammed Ali

ğŸ“º Create a Donkey Kong Country-ish Platformer in JS â€“ We donâ€™t see the DKC resemblance, but itâ€™s a solid 4 hourÂ screencast. Chris Courses

ğŸ“„ Implementing a 'Like' Button without Authentication Abhishek Saha

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Schedule-X 2: A Modern Event Calendar Component â€” Available in the form of React/Preact, Vue, Svelte, Angular, or plain JS components. Open source but with a premium version with extra features. GitHubÂ repo.

Tom Ã–sterlund

ğŸ§¹Â Vue Mess Detector: Code and Quality Analysis for VueÂ Projects â€” A static analysis tool that can catch various bugs and code quality issues in Vue-based projects, built atop rules from the Vue.js Style Guide and others. GitHubÂ repo.

Various Contributors

âœ‚ï¸ Cut Your QA Cycles Down from Hours to Minutes â€” QA Wolf's AI-native approach gets engineering teams to 80% automated end-to-end test coverage and helps them ship 2x faster by reducing QA cycles from hours toÂ minutes.

QA Wolf sponsor

Tesseract.js: Pure JS OCR for 100+ Languages â€” A port of the C++-based Tesseract library commonly used for extract text from images. The homepage has a live demo where you can drop your own images. GitHubÂ repo.

Tesseract Team

HumanifyJS: Deobfuscate JavaScript Code using ChatGPT â€” Thereâ€™s an in-depth explainer here. The primary feature is its ability to reverse the loss of meaningful variable and function names based on the context of theÂ code.

Jesse Luoto

Tests Are Dead. Meticulous Is Here â€” Automatically creates & maintains E2E UI tests. Zero flakes. Backed by YC, CTO of GitHub, CPO of Adobe, CEO ofÂ Vercel.

Meticulous sponsor

React Snap Carousel: DOM-First, Headless Carousel â€” Uses native browser scrolling and CSS scroll snap points for performance. Try out some of its features in its Storybook. The latest version adds support for infiniteÂ carousels.

Richard Scarrott

ğŸ’¡ For more React projects, check out our latest React newsletter.

  • Perspective 3.1 â€“ Streaming data viz and analytics component. The core is written in C++ and compiled to WebAssembly. The homepage shows it offÂ well.

  • NeutralinoJS 5.4 â€“ Lightweight cross-platform desktop appÂ framework.

  • websocket-as-promised 3.0 â€“ A Promise-based API for WebSockets.

  • Verdaccio 6.0 â€“ Lightweight local private npmÂ registry.

  • Rspack 1.0.7 â€“ Fast Rust-based webÂ bundler.

  • esbuild 0.24

#â€‹704 â€” September 12, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The State of ES5 on the Web â€” Some of the earlier JavaScript build tools focused on allowing developers to write modern JavaScript code that could still run on the browsers of the time by compiling code down to ES5. Time has moved on, but have the tools or popular libraries? Philip investigates, and shares someÂ recommendations.

Philip Walton

ğŸ“Š Â The Top 5000 npm Packages by Size, Downloads, and Traffic â€” An interesting Google Sheets spreadsheet listing the top 5000 npm packages by package size, weekly downloads, and weekly traffic. One package is responsible for 278 terabytes of traffic per week, but the top 5000 add up to several petabytes.

Google Sheets / danhorus

Run GitHub Actions Up to 2x Faster at Half the Cost â€” Blacksmith runs your GitHub Actions substantially faster by running them on modern gaming CPUs. Integrating Blacksmith is a one-line code change. 100+ companies like Ashby, Superblocks, and Slope use Blacksmith to help developers merge codeÂ faster.

Blacksmith sponsor

Announcing TypeScript 5.6 â€” The latest TypeScript has landed with full support for iterator helpers, support for arbitrary module identifiers, --noUncheckedSideEffectImports to import modules without importing any values, and more â€” all covered in the always thorough releaseÂ post.

Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft)

Is PHP the New JavaScript? â€” Iâ€™m no real fan of PHP, but thereâ€™s been a lot of discussion on social media around increased interest in PHP by developers whoâ€™d usually steer clear of it, largely thanks to Laravel. This post tells the basic story and explains what Laravel brings to theÂ table.

Dave Kiss (Mux)

IN BRIEF:

  • Cloudflare Workers has greatly improved its npm package support. The popular serverless platform now supports a lot more Node.js APIs.

  • ğŸ‰ They don't happen often, but Frontend Masters is currently running a sale on its courses, which now includes a JS performance learningÂ path.

  • The ESLint project has announced its latest version support policy with ESLint v8.x going into end of life next month.

  • ğŸ“… Vercel's Next.js Conf 2024 is taking place this October 24, both in person in San Francisco, as well asÂ online.

RELEASES:

  • Storybook 8.3 â€“ Frontend component and UIÂ workshop. Now with first class VitestÂ support.

  • ESLint 9.10 â€“ Now with types included.

  • pnpm 9.10, Jasmine 5.3, Relay 18.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

The Web's Clipboard, and How It Stores Data of Different Types â€” An interesting exploration of how things currently work with copy and pasting on the web, how different data types are treated, and what the Web Custom Formats proposal is puttingÂ forward.

Alex Harri JÃ³nsson

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, karma, jasmine, and more. Just added support for Node.js built-in node:testÂ framework!

Wallaby Team sponsor

Building the Same App Using Various Web Frameworks â€” A scientist at Amazon who usually works in Python with a minimum of JavaScript on the frontend wondered if a more modern web framework would suit him better in 2024. To try this out, he tried Next.js, SvelteKit, and the Python-flavored FastHTML.

Eugene Yan

Brand New Performance Features in Chrome DevTools â€” A helpful look into Chromeâ€™s updated Performance Panel and all the different metrics it shows off to help you improve the performance of yourÂ site.

Umar Hansa (DebugBear)

React and FormData â€” FormData is ironically both the â€˜newest and yet oldestâ€™ standard for accessing form data. Here are some practical ways for using it withÂ TypeScript.

Brad Westfall

Automate Neon Schema Changes with Drizzle and GitHub Actions â€” Learn about schema migrations and how they can be applied to a Neon database with Drizzle and GitHubÂ Actions.

Clerk sponsor

ğŸ“„ The Secrets of JavaScript's delete Operator Zachary Lee

ğŸ“„ Deploying a Next.js App to Production on Any Server Kurta Payjama

ğŸ“„ How to Create a Weekly Google Analytics Report That Posts to Slack Paul Scanlon

ğŸ“„ Top 10 Angular Architecture Mistakes You Really Want To Avoid Tomas Trajan

ğŸ“„ How to Fix ESLint Violations with AI Assistance Docker Labs

ğŸ“º Why You Should Use Redux in 2024 Mark Erikson

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Biome v1.9 Released; Turns One Year Old â€” Biome started life as a fork of Rome, a bold attempt to create an all-in-one â€˜frontend toolchainâ€™. As of v1.9, Biome can format and lint CSS, GraphQL, and JavaScript, does it very quickly, yet has 97% compatibility withÂ Prettier.

Victorien Elvinger & Biome Core Team

Express.js 5.0 Released â€” The seminal Node.js webapp library seemed to take a nap for a few years, but development was reinvigorated earlier this year. v5.0 brings a variety of modern tweaks and dependency updates, though it's still tagged next at the npm registry. (Official homepage and v5.x APIÂ docs.)

Wesley Todd

âœ‚ï¸ Cut Your QA Cycles Down from Hours to Minutes â€” QA Wolf's AI-native approach gets engineering teams to 80% automated end-to-end test coverage and helps them ship 2x faster by reducing QA cycles from hours toÂ minutes.

QA Wolf sponsor

Jimp 1.6: Manipulate Images without Native Dependencies â€” Most image libraries, such as Sharp, use native dependencies to do the heavy lifting, but Jimp can handle numerous formats directly for blurring, color tweaks, resizing, rotation, etc. Originally for Node, Jimp now works in the browser too â€“ GitHubÂ repo.

jimp Contributors

Valtio 2.0: Proxy State Made Simple â€” Turns objects into self-aware proxies so you can access state and subscribe to changes outside of components, add computed properties and more. Designed for React and compatible with Suspense, but can also be used with vanilla JS. â€“ GitHubÂ repo.

Daishi Kato

Violentmonkey: A Way to Run Userscripts in the Browser â€” There have been many extensions to run your own custom JavaScript automatically on certain Web pages over the years, but Violentmonkey seems to currently be one of the better and well maintained open source ones. GitHubÂ repo.

Violentmonkey Team

  • ğŸ” Orama 2.1 â€“ Dependency-free, full-text and vector search engine for all JSÂ runtimes, with typo tolerance, filters, facets, stemming, andÂ more.

  • create-fastify 5.0 â€“ Rapidly generate a Fastify project. It just takes npmÂ initÂ fastifyÂ app_name to getÂ started.

  • file-type 19.5 â€“ Detect the file type of a file, stream, orÂ data. Now with WebVTTÂ support.

  • TWGL.js 6.1 â€“ Helpers for working with low-level WebGL fromÂ JS.

  • ğŸ¨ Chroma.js 3.1 â€“ JavaScript color manipulationÂ library.

  • Pixi.js 8.4 â€“ Fast, flexible 2D WebGL renderer.
